mentions.context: NewSQL has been the latest technology in the big data management landscape, combining the scalability and availability of NoSQL with the consistency and usability of SQL.

NewSQL may also simplify data management, by removing the traditional separation between NoSQL and SQL (ingest data fast, query it with SQL), as well as between operational database and data warehouse / data lake (no more ETLs!).
NewSQL is the latest technology in the big data management landscape, enjoying a rapid growth in the database system and business intelligence (BI) markets.

NewSQL combines the scalability and availability of NoSQL with the consistency and usability of SQL (SQL here refers to SQL database systems, which is the common term used for relational database systems).

NewSQL may also simplify data management, by removing the traditional separation between NoSQL and SQL (ingest data fast, query it with SQL), as well as between the operational database and data warehouse or data lake (no more complex data extraction tools such as ETLs or ELTs!).
NewSQL database systems have different flavors and architectures.
NewSQL is a new class of database system that seeks to combine the advantages of NoSQL (scalability, availability) and SQL (ACID consistency and usability) systems.
NewSQL database systems come in different flavors, each targeted at different workloads and usages.
NewSQL database systems typically support more than one feature, but are often characterized by the one feature in which they excel, e.g., scalable ACID transactions.

NewSQL database systems can have one or more of these features and/or technologies, e.g., scalable operational, HTAP and main memory, or for the most advanced systems, HTAP with scalable transactions and polystore capabilities.
NewSQL combines the scalability and availability of NoSQL with the consistency and usability of SQL.
NewSQL systems come in different flavors, each targeted at different workloads and usages.
NewSQL database systems typically support more than one feature, but are often characterized by the one feature in which they excel, e.g., scalable ACID transactions.

NewSQL may also simplify data management, by removing the traditional separation between NoSQL and SQL (ingest data fast, query it with SQL), as well as between operational database and data warehouse / data lake (no more ETLs!).
NewSQL is relatively new, and there is much room for research.
Spanner uses traditional locking and 2PC and provides serializability as isolation level.
Spanner uses real time to timestamp transactions, while LeanXcale uses logical time, which avoids having to rely on a complex real-time infrastructure.
Spanner uses real time to timestamp transactions, while LeanXcale uses logical time.

LeanXcale adopts an approach in which transactions are timestamped with a logical time and committed transactions are made visible progressively as gaps in the serialization order are filled by newly committed transactions.
LeanXcale is an advanced NewSQL HTAP database system with full SQL and polystore support with scalable ACID transactions.
LeanXcale provides full SQL functionality over relational tables with JSON columns.
LeanXcale scales out transactional management [9] by decomposing the ACID properties and scaling each of them independently but in a composable manner.
Spanner [3] is an advanced NewSQL database system with full SQL and scalable ACID transactions.
Before NewSQL, these applications could be developed, but using multiple systems and typically at a very high price.
We characterized NewSQL systems by their main new features, which are: scalable ACID transactions, main memory support, polystore, and HTAP support.

Today, only a few NewSQL systems have solved this problem, e.g., Spanner and LeanXcale, which we described in more details.
For this purpose, Spanner implements an internal service called TrueTime that provides the current time and its current accuracy.
For logical time, LeanXcale uses two services: the commit sequencer and the snapshot server.
Clients can access LeanXcale with any analytics tool using a JDBC or ODBC driver.
Examples of popular NewSQL database systems are LeanXcale, Spanner, CockroachDB, EsgynDB, SAP HANA, MemSQL, NuoDB, and Splice Machine.
Currently, only a few NewSQL database systems have solved this problem, e.g., the LeanXcale NewSQL database system that includes a highly scalable transaction manager [9] and a polystore [6].
Storage management in Spanner is made scalable by leveraging Bigtable, a wide column data store.
Using multiversioning, Spanner also implements read-only transactions that read over the snapshot at the current time.
To deal with deadlocks, Spanner adopts deadlock avoidance using a wound-and-wait approach thereby eliminating the bottleneck of deadlock detection.
LeanXcale is an advanced NewSQL HTAP database system with full SQL and polystore support with scalable ACID transactions.
Spanner [3] is an advanced NewSQL database system with full SQL and scalable ACID transactions.
An important capability of LeanXcale is polystore access using the scripting mechanism of the CloudMdsQL query language [6,7].
Graph database systems, e.g., Neo4J and Ori-entDB, are specialized in storing and querying graphs efficiently.
Document database systems, e.g., MongoDB and CouchBase, use a data representation, such as JSON or XML, and provide an API to access these data or sometimes a query language.
Key-value database systems, e.g., DynamoDB and Cassandra, are schemaless so they are totally flexible with the stored data.

In this paper, we make the case for NewSQL, introducing their basic principles from distributed database systems and illustrating with Spanner and LeanXcale, two of the most advanced systems in terms of scalable transaction management.

In this paper, we made the case for NewSQL, which is enjoying a fast growth in the database system and BI markets in the context of big data.

Main memory database systems, such as MemDB, SAP HANA and VoltDB, keep all data in memory, which enables processing queries at the speed of memory without being limited by the I/O bandwidth and latency.
The architecture of the most advanced NewSQL database systems is interesting, typically using a key-value store to provide a first level of scalability (see Fig. 4).
In the rest of this section, we present NewSQL in more detail, and illustrate with two of the most advanced systems in terms of scalable transaction management: Spanner and LeanXcale.

We gave a first in-depth presentation of NewSQL in a tutorial at the IEEE Big Data 2019 conference [15], where we provide a taxonomy of NewSQL database systems based on major dimensions including targeted workloads, capabilities and implementation techniques.
Our taxonomy in [15] is useful to understand NewSQL database systems based on major dimensions including targeted workloads (OLTP, OLAP, HTAP), features and implementation techniques.

Main memory database systems, such as MemDB, SAP HANA and VoltDB, keep all data in memory, which enables processing queries at the speed of memory without being limited by the I/O bandwidth and latency.

Examples of popular NewSQL database systems are LeanXcale, Spanner, CockroachDB, EsgynDB, SAP HANA, MemSQL, NuoDB, and Splice Machine.
Furthermore, in addition to scalable transactions, LeanXcale provides polytore support, to access multiple data stores such as HDFS and NoSQL, and non-intrusive elasticity.
By providing online analytics over operational data, NewSQL opens up new opportunities in many application domains where real-time decisions are critical.

In this paper, we make the case for NewSQL, introducing their basic principles from distributed database systems and illustrating with Spanner and LeanXcale, two of the most advanced systems in terms of scalable transaction management.

We gave a first in-depth presentation of NewSQL in a tutorial at the IEEE Big Data 2019 conference [15], where we provide a taxonomy of NewSQL database systems based on major dimensions including targeted workloads, capabilities and implementation techniques.

In this paper, we make the case for NewSQL, introducing their basic principles from distributed database systems and illustrating with Spanner and LeanXcale, two of the most advanced systems in terms of scalable transaction management.

The data stores that can be accessed range from distributed raw data files (e.g., HDFS through parallel SQL queries) to NoSQL database systems (e.g., MongoDB, where queries can be expressed as Ja-vaScript programs).
In the rest of this section, we present NewSQL in more detail, and illustrate with two of the most advanced systems in terms of scalable transaction management: Spanner and LeanXcale.
In the rest of this section, we present NewSQL in more detail, and illustrate with two of the most advanced systems in terms of scalable transaction management: Spanner and LeanXcale.

By blending capabilities only available in different kinds of database systems such as fast data ingestion and SQL queries and by providing online analytics over operational data, NewSQL opens up new opportunities in many application domains where real-time decisions are critical.

By blending capabilities only available in different kinds of database systems such as fast data ingestion and SQL queries and by providing online analytics over operational data, NewSQL opens up new opportunities in many application domains where realtime decision is critical.
Today, shared-nothing clusters are cost-effective as servers can be off-the-shelf components (multicore processor, memory and disk) connected by a low-latency network such as Infiniband or Myrinet.

Examples of research directions include: JSON and SQL integration, to seamlessly access both relational and JSON data, and thus combine the advantages of SQL and NoSQL with one database system; streaming SQL to combine data streams and NewSQL data; integration with popular big data frameworks such as Spark to perform analytics and machine learning; and defining specific NewSQL HTAP benchmarks.

This characterization has been useful for all subsequent editions, to include the new developments in many topics, which are reflected in Fig. 1, which identifies four main categories: the early clientserver database systems, with limited distribution; the recent distributed and parallel systems, including NoSQL and NewSQL with high distribution; the P2P systems with high distribution and autonomy; and the multidatabase systems and polystores with high distribution, autonomy and heterogeneity.

Examples of research directions include: JSON and SQL integration, to seamlessly access both relational and JSON data, and thus combine the advantages of SQL and NoSQL with one database system; streaming SQL to combine data streams and NewSQL data; integration with popular big data frameworks such as Spark to perform analytics and machine learning; and defining specific NewSQL HTAP benchmarks.
